"129"	"343"	"Jolie O'Dell"	"jolieodell"	"4"	"0"	"2009-09-22 23:32:29 UTC"	"(written spring 2009)

For some cosmic/hormonal reason, I hated the Pixelpipe live demo I saw last week at SF New Tech. After TechCrunch’s review, I spewed some bile into the comments section about how there are already too many value-free aggregating/status pushing services and went on with my life. I now must nibble lightly on my words; Pixelpipe doesn’t suck.

The suprisingly simple three-click process for adding most “pipes” is among the fastest processes I’ve seen yet. Unfortunately, it’s giving me unidentifiable technical problems with pushing status updates to Facebook (mystery error message FTW?), and double-posting to TwitPic/Twitter (see the all-important redundancy note at the beginning of this gargantuan post). And I still can’t get the background image upload form to work.

Customization: Allows for custom or colored background/headline on a hosted page; but so far, I haven’t been able to make that work.

Content Posting: Uploads status updates/microblogs, photos, videos, audio, and other files; then pushes the content to any relevant social sites you’ve linked.

Mobile Functionality: Email, MMS, an iPhone app, an Android app, etc. Seems poised for mobile greatness.

Roasted: Medium rare. Stick a fork in it and send feedback to @brettb."
"130"	"1007"	"Jolie O'Dell"	"jolieodell"	"4"	"1"	"2009-09-22 23:44:46 UTC"	"Many users have long sought the ultimate app for mashing up Twitter and online video. Several services have emerged in this space, but many that we tested have been found wanting.

Today, we've been playing with TwitVid.com and the new, free TwitVid iPhone app. Both have greatly impressed us with a simple, well-integrated interface and just the right balance of great function without feature bloat. Does TwitVid have what it takes to win the Twitter-come-video game?

With a range of options for capturing and uploading video, we think TwitVid stands a good chance.

Includes option for iPhone, webcam, and uploads."
"131"	"1303"	"Jolie O'Dell"	"jolieodell"	"3"	"0"	"2009-09-22 23:46:30 UTC"	"The site, which is still in its infancy, gives users a three-step process for sending music via Twitter. First, the user finds the song. As aforementioned, the song could be on a website, on a user's hard drive, or in the SongTwit library, which seems to consist of third party-hosted audio clips (this seems fine for web-based sharing, but we wonder how well it will work for various mobile devices). If the user is working from the SongTwit library, he is presented with a range of selections and is able to preview the song/video before it goes out as a tweet. There are a few flaws of the service, aside from the DM-less-ness. No downloads from these pages are yet available, and they're still working on the broken pause button on the media players. Still, the search function really does help save time that would likely have been spent trolling YouTube for clips of that one Venga Boys song from 1999. And that's what the Internet is for, no?"

"275"	"170"	"Ewan Spence"	"Ewan"	"5"	"0"	"2009-09-24 00:58:46 UTC"	"My comprehensive review is online at http://www.allaboutsymbian.com/reviews/item/Gravity.php

Summary: It's still one of the most professional apps on S60 in the last few years. I'd argue it's better than most of the desktop Twitter clients as well, and easily an equal of Tweetdeck (the most popular third party Twitter client, after using the native web site). I've no hesitation in awarding it a score of 90 and an AAS Mega-app award, and urge anyone on Twitter to take a look."

"278"	"191"	"Jared Rea"	"jaredr"	"4"	"0"	"2009-09-24 00:59:18 UTC"	"I use HootSuite in my work-life and it's a very impressive client, though a bit slow across the board. The ability to schedule tweets and statistics for the built-in URL shortening are invaluable, and the relative ease of use will make involving more people than just myself on the Twittering process a snap. 

Switching between content panes, however, IS a pain. HootSuite can chug at times and its URL shortener comes with a content bar that can add a lot of load times for your readers during peek hours. Still, it's hard to argue with what they give you, especially considering its free at the moment."

"423"	"1129"	"Chris Martinez"	"ChrisMartinez"	"4"	"0"	"2009-09-24 04:46:56 UTC"	"This is a fast way to share pics and videos on the iPhone on twitter. It is a paid app (at the moment it costs $2.99), although it does display ads on your pages (tisk, tisk).

It has support to change the quality of the pic/video you're uploading so you can attain faster uploading speeds on slower networks or vice versa.

It does not have support for private accounts or all uploads are public. (boo)

The design of the pages is dark and hip.

The short URL allows you to include a big description of the attached media.

Purportedly, Tweet Reel has developed an API which would allow apps to allow direct uploading of media to Tweet Reel."

"436"	"1123"	"Indé Fjölnir"	"indecisiviously"	"5"	"0"	"2009-09-24 05:12:48 UTC"	"Two weeks ago, I thought the funniest person on twitter was Eugene Mirman.  Then, I found Favstar.  Eugene is still in my top 50, but he's far from the top 'o the list.

Favstar is an untapped glory hole of mirth and joy.  Sure, you can go anywhere to find a few hundred RTd ""jokes,"" but if you want to find the real comedians of the interwebs, spend a few hours (or weeks) combing through Favstar.  You'll end up dumping all those celebrities you came to Twitter for in the first place, and replacing them with people not too different from yourself.

And you'll be inspired.  They will make you laugh, and you will respond.  You'll discover people who appreciate your words.  You will love them and spend hours trying to please them.  Your entire waking life will revolve around poop jokes and clever ways to improve on the meme of the day.  Pantslessness and bacon will always be on your mind.

Not that Favstar is an addiction, or anything.  I can quit anytime I want.

But to people who already are addicted to Twitter, Favstar is like your designated driver, enabling your self-destructive idiocy by rewarding absurdity.

And for that, I shall always love it."

"514"	"1161"	"Nathan Rein"	"nbr"	"5"	"0"	"2009-09-24 13:04:31 UTC"	"Amplify mashes up Wordpress, the Clipmarks.com clipping tool, and social services (Twitter, Facebook, and Delicious) to create an intuitive and quick way to save and share rich web content. After installing the Firefox extension, you can grab bite-sized chunks (up to 1000 characters) from any web page, post the clipping to your own Amplify site, and broadcast your clip to your followers and contacts on Twitter and Facebook. Clips can include almost anything you find on a web page -- formatted text, images, even embedded video. Amplify also saves your clips to Delicious and Clipmarks, and they have recently added more social features which make it easy to follow clips and recommendations from your contacts. The site also incorporates flexible, automated retweeting, commenting and recommending features. Highly recommended. "

"554"	"1213"	"Mark Gammon"	"markgammon"	"4"	"1"	"2009-09-24 14:48:27 UTC"	"4.5 stars. I've been a Mixero user since near the beginning. I really like the app, though it does take some getting used to. The interface can seem complex with contexts, active lists, etc... but it doesn't take too long before these make sense and become difficult to live without. I love that the app keeps my groups, lists, contexts synced between multiple computers/devices.  That means when I add people to new lists, create groups, etc on my home computer, when I sign in at work... all of these changes are synced. Love that. The app is still in development, but the devs are very responsive to feedback and are continuing to grow and refine the features.  The alpha iPhone app (not yet publicly available) is also very cool, with many of the same features of the desktop client.  The mobile version does have some drawbacks (loading time) but it's still early and the team is actively working to address user's wants and needs for the app.  Overall, definitely worth checking out Mixero."

"659"	"429"	"Pete"	"prp2"	"5"	"0"	"2009-09-24 18:46:12 UTC"	"SocialScope feels the most like a ""native"" BlackBerry application as I've ever seen for Twitter, and its integration with your address book is a pretty handy thing. The tabs, grouping functions a la Tweetdeck and threaded DMs make it a joy to use. In fact, I hardly ever tweet from my laptop anymore since I'm always on my BlackBerry anyway. Being able to view fullscreen pictures within tweets (any tweet containing a Twitpic link, for example) is an excellent feature, and the same can be done with their Facebook integration as well, complete with flick scrolling.

There are some bugs to be worked through, occasional display issues and such, and it doesn't have trending topic support like some of the other clients (UberTwitter, TwiXtreme) do. That's hardly a deterrent, though. Bottom line is, if you can get an invite to this, definitely do it. You won't be disappointed."

My favourite feature is the seamless landscape keyboard. With Tweetie, you have to change your settings to apply a landscape keyboard -- and then you ALWAYS have to use it! With Twittelator, you can change it on the fly, just by changing the orientation of your iDevice. Perfect.

It's a bit sad that, in such a feature-packed application, that's my absolute, number 1 favourite feature, but I love the landscape keyboard. But then, sometimes I just want to use one hand, so if I don't want to, I don't HAVE to use landscape. It's great.

My one complaint is the GUI.
Now, while it's not ugly by any means, it definitely needs a facelift. I contemplate going back to Tweetie sometimes just for the UI... I love brilliant design, and Tweetie wins in that category.
But, I always end up going back to Twittelator for all the great features. Definitely an awesome client."

"740"	"1286"	"Rob Hudson"	"vivosity"	"4"	"1"	"2009-09-24 22:44:26 UTC"	"I have used Threadsy for about a week now and have grown to love it for the following aspects: unified inbox for multiple Gmail accounts and for multiple Twitter accounts. I can use one search request to look for emails across accounts. I can post status updates to my Twitter accounts and Facebook. Setup and daily usage is quick and easy. 

HOWEVER, I do have some issues with it. I'm not thrilled with having to type my login info each day because it can't remember my login (web app). Unlike TweetDeck (which I use at the same time), it is not very clear which Twitter account(s) will receive my tweet. I have to click a dropdown to see. In a rush, I have sent to the wrong account. I have had issues with other services when I tried to authenticate and they didn't know which account I was intending because I was logged into them all. Also, the email inbox shows no indication of which account each message came from. A simple notation would be nice.

In short, the power of being logged in with multiple identities also means that there is a responsibility for Threadsy to make it clear what identity I am using to communicate with at each action. TweetDeck handles this with check boxes that are always evident.

I have high hopes for a client that can aggregate all of my communication IDs while honoring the separation that warrants multiple IDs in the first place. 

For now, I will use a few apps concurrently.

PS - add LinkedIn and Plaxo status to my ""unbound"" list."

"969"	"151"	"Mike Champion"	"graysky"	"5"	"0"	"2009-09-26 01:52:30 UTC"	"I've been digging it, and on like the 3rd time I used it let me know a friend was at the same restaurant. Seems to work best in the city and among those who go to a lot of events and bars."
"970"	"1123"	"Ben Ward"	"BenWard"	"4"	"0"	"2009-09-26 02:17:51 UTC"	"Favstar really is the best tool for checking who's faved your tweets. It's full of detailed views for both recent and overall popularity views of your posts, as well as identifying your biggest fans. It's a well presented wealth of data. Favstar seems to do an excellent job of crawling for faves, and collects the faves from all users as best it can. Favstar is a tool that's really great for personal stats gathering.

You can also view the popular tweets from across Twitter as a whole. The flipside of Favstar's indiscriminate crawling is that the stats for Twitter as a whole are less eclectic than on Favrd. On Favstar, you will have to scroll past the inanity posted by the Jonas Brothers, for example. (They appear to be a sufficiently unstoppable entity from the weight of their fanbase.) Favrd, on the other hand, has filtered out almost everyone that faves the Jonas Brothers, so you never see them. Favstar's views are more truthful and complete, and for the most part still a perfectly good way of discovering new content. There's just a hint of the Trending Topics/Retweet problem, where the outright wisdom of the crowd is not always the best way.

Fantastic, useful tool, constantly and passionately maintained by Tim. Great job."
"971"	"967"	"Ben Ward"	"BenWard"	"5"	"0"	"2009-09-26 02:29:18 UTC"	"Without a doubt the Daddy of Twitter apps. The heritage to the original Mac OSX version remains, but the interface has evolved beautiful over the years into something that's refined and brilliant. Twitterrific is unique in that it merged tweets, @mentions and messages into a single stream, rather than distinct sections. This is by far the best way to read Twitter. You just scroll and it's all there. Rather than segregate types of content, you can instead filter the stream to show ‘just @mentions’ or ‘just DMs’, so you can get the same views as other apps, it's just implemented much, much better.

It has everything you could want and more: Multiple accounts, saved searches, an address book feature to look up Twitter users by name, photo and video upload, fantastic conversation views and functions to to find the follow-ups to people's questions.

As an iPhone purist, I highly recommend choosing the ‘Basic’ theme, as that has the app looking native on the iPhone, but all the themes are well built."
"972"	"788"	"Ben Ward"	"BenWard"	"2"	"1"	"2009-09-26 02:35:38 UTC"	"Useful, I concede, but annoying to see photo uploads getting fragmented away from Flickr. Also, given that this is a service dedicated to Twitter which is, y'know, all about mobile clients, why on earth is there no picture-centric iPhone-sized view?

The clunky desktop layout loads up no matter which device you use, so when it loads up the picture isn't the first thing you see. That's a pretty massive drawback for a Twitter-only service."

"978"	"966"	"Ben Ward"	"BenWard"	"3"	"1"	"2009-09-26 04:07:39 UTC"	"Note this page is for the Mac OSX version of Twitterrific, the stunningly-good iPhone version has its own page (search: “Twitterrific for iPhone”.)

Twitterrific is one of the earliest desktop Twitter clients. It pioneered the integrated stream view (friends + @mentions + dms all in one list, rather than separated), and it's that feature that keeps me using it still.

There are other, far richer featured Twitter applications than Twitter for OSX. There are apps with slicker replies integration, messaging and integrated search, retweeting, photos and all sorts. This Twitter client is crude (you'll be typing ‘d @friend’ by hand for DMs), but it's fast, it's clean, stable and has excellent keyboard shortcuts.

I would dearly love to see a full update to bring Twitterrific kicking and screaming back into action and on par with its iPhone sibling; it's getting a little antiquated. But despite that, the combined stream view is the killer feature and I can't see myself moving away without that."
"979"	"602"	"Ben Ward"	"BenWard"	"3"	"0"	"2009-09-26 04:12:55 UTC"	"Tweetie is good, and full featured, but I find the UI to be a little cumbersome. Moving between lots of separate views and having to load tweets in standalone pages to interact with their content is just a little cumbersome; I compare this to Twitterrific where you can do an awful lot more interaction inline.

There are also a few features (such as search, and loading up Twitter users by username) which are tacked together into a ‘More…’ menu, lacking better integration.

It's good, but not the best."

"1064"	"13"	"Anita Campbell"	"smallbiztrends"	"4"	"0"	"2009-09-27 14:02:44 UTC"	"I started using Adjix because I saw Guy Kawasaki using it, and assumed it had something to recommend it.

I do not use the advertising portion of Adjix (which I would consider intrusive).  Rather, I use it merely for convenience and analytics.

At the time I started using it, Adjix was one of the few applications that tracked how many clicks you got on a shortened URL.  Also, Adjix allows you to schedule tweets in advance, something I find convenient if I happen upon something on the Web, but have just tweeted 2 minutes ago -- I don't want to overwhelm followers with too frequent tweets.  And it has two bookmarklets that live on my Firefox browser, which make tweeting a page while browsing the Web tres convenient.

However, I feel that other apps are coming out that do many of these same things, and Adjix is falling behind in its product development.  I have not seen any major improvements.  And it is still annoying that you get logged out after 15 minutes. that makes it multiple clicks to get in and see scheduled tweets, stats on how many click-throughs you got, etc.  While I still use it, I'd like to see product improvements soon."

"1085"	"170"	"Leonard Challis"	"LeonardChallis"	"5"	"0"	"2009-09-28 07:52:48 UTC"	"While previously using Twibble, a free Symbian twitter program, I wanted more power to do everything I do on a desktop machine. I downloaded a demo of Gravity and after minutes of using it I went to buy it. It is very, very cheap for what it is and I would, and do, recommend it to everyone with a Symbian based phone.

The features include everything you could want; timeline, replies, DMs, trending topics, custom searches, followers, following, twitpic, identica, and more recently facebook and GPS integration.

It is a self-updating app, and you can install the latest betas right from within the app itself. The GUI is intuitive, uncluttered and incredibly slick and pretty. One screen for each feature, and you're just scrolling right or left to view them. I love how I can roam without a connection then come back and I will be at the same Tweet as I left it with so I can catch up.

There's plenty more I could say about this app, but I urge you all to go and have the pleasure of experiencing it for yourself. If they did a desktop version of this app it would blow Tweetdeck away.

Oh one final thing -- before purchasing I also contacted customer support. They were quick to reply, very friendly and courteous and answered anything I had to ask quickly and sufficiently. A definite 5-star piece of software, without a bad review. For me, it's the killer app."

"1238"	"1213"	"Jim Bergman"	"jimbergman"	"5"	"1"	"2009-09-30 05:55:21 UTC"	"This is now my primary twitter client, for a number of reasons: the program is easy to use, and lets me create a number of groups (currently I use 14). It is easy to see when there are updates to my groups and searches. It doesn't have many of the faults of TweetDeck (like memory leaks, missed tweets, group syncing problems to server, sluggish performance or annoying quirks). It hide itself neatly to the icon bar or to one side of the screen. It is still in beta, so there are a few minor issues. Looking forward to beta testing the iPhone app with full sync with the desktop. I tested Seesmic, Brizzly, Tweetie (Mac), TweetDeck and about 10 iPhone apps. This is the best of the bunch."

The most beautiful feature of the Twii is the fact that it starts almost instantly. When I have an idea or thought to tweet, I don't want to be waiting 5 minutes for tweets to load. I need to post now and fast. Twii lets me do that.

I HIGHLY recommend Twii as your posting app for the iPhone!"

"1794"	"191"	"Jon@Ringhorne.com"	"ringhorne"	"4"	"0"	"2009-10-07 23:55:05 UTC"	"I discovered Twitter (became a user) about a year ago (Fall 2008). Not long after that, I noticed all the apps (you'll see ""from Hootsuite"" under tweets, or some other app/device ID) for tweeting. 

For browser-based tweeting, Hootsuite is VERY customizable, and I ENJOY that and being able to follow ANY tweets streams I choose. Best of all, for heavy users, it provides the ability to access several Twitter accounts at once, to see and send tweets from them. If you want to follow certain hash (#...) marks, keywords, or specific users, you can set it up to follow anything from a core location.  I have a column of selected news feeds only, for example. It lets you do easy retweets, simple follows of others, and other cool features. I am so hooked I struggle on the regular Twitter site now!

I know, from using it, that Hootsuite works fine in Safari and Firefox. Twitter gets bogged down, so it gets bogged down, at times. If your browser is being stubborn, reload you page, that's usually the fix.

With far less effort than you might guess, until you try, Hootsuite turns Twitter blogging into a gaggle of streams. I strongly suggest Hootsuite!"

"2063"	"96"	"Mathieu De Coensel"	"mathiepe"	"5"	"0"	"2009-10-09 15:49:29 UTC"	"This is a difficult application to write a review about, because this is a Twitter-application base, and Twitter is not really Digsby's core-business. But still it does a very good job...it handles the tweets a bit different as Digsby puts them in a chronological order. You can create groups, save searches, see the Twitter trends and instantly reply, retweet, favorite every tweet in just one click. Because of the chronological order it is easier to follow conversations between the people you follow and if you still missed out on something you can easily click the ""in reply too..."" link to see to which tweet one is replying too. I use Digsby as my one and only Twitter-application on pc (besides web) and I'm very satisfied with it.

It's also customizable, just like everything else in Digsby's broad service (chatting, e-mail, social-networking, it does as good as everything in one simple and good-looking application), as you can reorder your saved searches or groups & update-intervals for your timeline, replies, dm's and searches."

Later that day I got a DM from one of the devs at RunKeeper asking for specifics about the problem; he wanted to know what happened so that he could find a way to prevent it from happening in the future. I've made plenty of support calls to vendors for other apps in the past and usually I get the feeling that I'm bothering them by asking for help...these guys go out looking for the problems so that they can fix them before anyone else encounters it. "2373"	"96"	"Jai'prakash"	"DarkDippy"	"5"	"0"	"2009-10-13 14:53:17 UTC"	"Fantastic app with great Twitter integration. 
- Separate your feed into groups either focusing on the tweets you want to filtering out the ones you don't. 
- Easily reply or retweet new tweets directly from the pop-up notification without really leaving the app you're working in. 
- Thread tweets, thus following the preceding tweets (and essential conversation) of @replies.
- Digsby will help shorten multiple URLs and whole tweets.
- Save your searches as ""Twitter groups"".

All the above PLUS a fully integrated Facebook home feed, LinkedIn feed, Instant Messaging and Email.

Granted there are a few features (group chat, that are lacking but Digsby isn't officially out of beta yet. It is a kick-ass all-in-one application that well and truly beats the competition in features and ease of use.

Just some minor comments/suggestions:
1. It would be great to be able to delete/update/pause/etc many scheduled tweets at once, instead of having to carry out the action to each tweet individually.
2. Once a scheduled tweet has been sent, it would be desired that they not appear in the scheduled queue.
3. Personally, I don't like the tabbed list format, where there is no URL for each ""page"" of scheduled tweets.
4. Sometimes I'd like to see more than 20 scheduled tweets per page. When I change the number of scheduled tweets I see on one page, it adjusts that straight away. But once I move to another ""page"", it goes back to displaying 20 tweets only.

Thanks for the great website :)"

"2454"	"96"	"Debbie YM Loh"	"debslym"	"5"	"0"	"2009-10-14 05:07:46 UTC"	"I use it for all my e-mail and IM accounts. It's fast, reliable and also enables pop menues that are unique to the client. For example, you can toggle your stealth settings on your Yahoo IM. 

Also love these settings:
- Alert Me when (Digsy alerts you when a contact, say, goes offline etc)
- Various formats of arranging and ordering your buddy list around (perfect for an organised person like me)
- Privacy settings (disable the other person from knowing whether you are typing or otherwise)

The drawbacks are small:
- Can't unblock an MSN contact from here
- Limited skins, at least, I don't know how to get more skin varieties

Digsby rocks.

http://debslym.wordpress.com"

"2977"	"326"	"Kat Nagel"	"katnagel"	"5"	"1"	"2009-10-26 13:30:45 UTC"	"I've been testing Peoplebrowsr side-by-side with Tweetdeck, Seesmic Desktop, Nambu, Mixero, and Tweetie. While all have their strengths and weeknesses, Peoplebrowsr seems to meet my needs best. (1) It's the only one of the bunch that lets me scroll backwards through my streams to catch up on everything I've missed. Other apps stop short at 1hr, 3hrs, 1day, or only scroll back through messages tweeted while I was online. With Peoplebrowsr, there are no gaps. (2) Several apps claim to manage multiple accounts. Peoplebrowsr delivers. It's easy to see which account is active for posting, I can post an individual tweet from any or all of my accounts, and -- no matter which account I use to log in -- I can select any account to follow/unfollow someone interesting. No more logging out of one account, then logging into another account -- BLISS!"

U - update
R- Reply
E- Reply
T- Top
B - Bottom
Space - Pg Dn
Shift-Space - Pg Up
F - Follow
P - refresh
O - refresh
L - ReTweet
K - Reply to All
A - Account Screen
D - Direct Message
S- Search"

"3375"	"604"	"Dr. Seth Greenblatt"	"Dr_SG"	"5"	"3"	"2009-11-07 03:48:16 UTC"	"I try every new version of every Mac Desktop Twitter client.  I changed my primary client at least once a week, until Tweetie was released.  Since the first time I tried it, Tweetie has been my primary client.  I still try out all the new releases with an open mind, but I haven't switched yet. I have a feeling I'll become even more set in my ways after v.2 comes out.

I find the app to be performant, easy to use, and aesthetically pleasing. It allows you to save searches, and even though Tweetie is a 'single column' client, I can take my searches and tear them off into their own window/column.

There are only two areas that I feel could be improved.  As mentioned in other reviews, groups would be useful.  I would also like a view whereby I can see either all the DMs I have received, split out from the DMs I have sent. Now, all DMs are grouped by conversation w/specific users.

All-in-all, I like Tweetie better than any of the other desktop clients, even though the other clients have improved by leaps and bounds."

"3431"	"1335"	"Howard Lake"	"howardlake"	"5"	"1"	"2009-11-08 19:59:23 UTC"	"A very useful tool to help present a Twitter feed on a web page or blog. It was easy to use and customise, taking me just a few minutes. I placed it on the front page of my site in order to present tweets from a major international fundraising conference.

The feed picked up a hashtag used by those at the conference and those commenting from afar.

The feed had to remain there for five days, and Tweetcooker performed well. There were a few drops in service during that period, but I suspect they were more down to Twitter than Tweetcooker.

Tweetcooker was noticed by many site users, and I got good feedback from those that commented. I'd certainly use it again.

Improvements I'd suggest would include more choice in font faces, colours and layout.

Overall, a very effective widget."

2) There is no tweet count on Dm's as there is on @ messages
2) I have to keep reposting Dm's & @ replies as 2 times out of 5 they fail to post the first time
3) There is no way to check your Dm messages to a person as there is on mo tweets
4) the Update success message doesn't automatically go away. you have to manually remove it.
5) sliding your finger to access give you lots of information which is good & access to profiles & a wealth of info.
6) Touching the profile pic give you access to the users profile as well where you have to scroll down to to find the Direct message or @reply ,Wouldn't it be better to have just @reply Dm & chat available for a speed?
7) There is no text sizing available
8) when you dm someone it should say who u are sending a direct message to just in case u have made and error. 
9) sometimes when you cancel & dm or @ reply & go to choose a new person to dm or @ reply to, the last persons @ reply i.e. @noname is still in the field.
10) Conclusion. I feel if i had the chance to have reviewed it on a trial (not the 24hr windows marketplace one as by the time i had managed to contact them as the site kept crashing it was too late to get a refund) Then I wouldn't have purchased it as in my opinion it should still be in the beta testing stage & not passed for release to buy it. "4119"	"1899"	"GregAtGist"	"GregAtGist"	""	"0"	"2009-12-17 20:52:49 UTC"	"Using CRM, Email, and Social Media information, Gist helps you to know more about who you know.

What is Gist?
Gist is an online service that collects, aggregates, and prioritizes information about your contacts.

Gist prioritizes that information based on the information in your email.

Our goal is to shrink the time for you to get to a key moment of insight.

Today, you use a variety of sources to find this information.  Gist helps you to view this information in one place and to make that view available to you in the places where you spend your time:

    * in your email: Gist Desktop integrates with Outlook to give you contextual information about a contact, and the Gist web application connects to your Gmail or other IMAP email;
    * in your applications: Gist helps you improve your ability to see leads in Salesforce;
    * on the go: Gist for the iPhone is available for you wherever you are.


Why do you need to use Gist?
Use Gist to:

    * make sense of it all -- gain an overall view of your contacts
    * prioritize your contact -- use the view to find your most important contacts
    * plan your next steps -- see the pattern of information you interact with these contacts
    * and act on that information -- share information, initiate contact, or react to information


When do you use Gist?
Use Gist in three core scenarios:
1) Morning Coffee -- spend 10-20 minutes in your morning reviewing new information produced by your most important contacts.  Use the Gist dashboard to identify, review, and act on this information.
2) Prepare for a meeting -- review the Gist profile for a person you are meeting in an upcoming meeting.  You can do this on the go with the Gist iPhone application, and even email ahead easily if you're running a few minutes behind for that important meeting.
3) Find something you know you have -- mine your inbox for information that a contact share with you, be it an attachment, a link, or the title of a recent email, and use that link to jump back into your email client to review the original correspondence."

"4700"	"598"	"Media Owls"	"MediaOwls"	"5"	"1"	"2010-01-20 22:26:02 UTC"	"Ditto to the previous poster..! I also work at a PR agency -- full disclosure, our company just started working with MediaFunnel late December but we had been using the service for several months before any business relationship started. We were genuinely ardent fans long before we ever hoped to have them as a client!

MediaFunnel has really made our ""team tweeting"" much more efficient. Before we discovered this tool, we were writing tweets, pasting into emails, sending off to the account manager to review and post -- it was a lot of hassle and frankly a bit disorganized. Now we can all work from the same dashboard and be much more topical, responsive and relevant.

Its new ""Guest Tweet"" opens up the company's Twitter account to those outside the business, like fans, customers, anyone who has had an experience with the brand and would like to comment. The editorial review function is a safety measure that helps to ease clients' concerns and Guest Tweets have brought a lot of useful, interesting commentary!

With the Alerts function, we can monitor our brands and ""assign tweets"" so the right person is responding and we're able to answer DMs and other queries quickly. Personally, I like the clean user interface, it's clear and intuitive without a lot of extraneous activity jumbling up the screen. I think any business, non-profit, club, band or any organization that's engaged in a group Twitter effort would find MediaFunnel an excellent product."

"4710"	"2349"	"Joe Workman"	"joeworkman"	"5"	"0"	"2010-01-21 02:18:54 UTC"	"I have been using Kiwi for a couple of months and absolutely love it! I have tried pretty much every major twitter app out there: Twitterific, TweetDeck (Adobe AIR is awful), Tweetie, now with Kiwi, I could not imagine going back. 

Kiwi has a ton of beautiful themes that allow you to customize the look and feel of your Twitter experience. While it sports a very simple and easy to use interface, Kiwi is very powerful behind the scenes. Instead of just allowing you to manage Twitter via your account timeline, Kiwi allows you to define you own custom timelines based off of any twitter account (even yours) as well as searches. You can create as many timelines as you want! I currently have 3 timelines setup so that I can quickly find the tweets that I care about: Photography, Real Estate, and Rapidweaver. And they are all based off of multiple search criteria. That is VERY COOL!

The other cool feature is the very useful rules system. You can build your own set of rules to highlight certain special tweets that you want to draw attention to. Or maybe you create a rule to hide all of those annoying spam tweets that we all get.

Kiwi is by far the most beautiful, flexible and powerful Twitter app out there."

"4765"	"1196"	"Justin Freid"	"JustinFreid"	"4"	"0"	"2010-01-23 03:36:19 UTC"	"IM+ is primarily (as its name implies) an instant messaging app for the iPhone. It fairs very well, however, as a lightweight Twitter client, too.
First, along with pushing regular IMs to your iPhone, IM+ can push any combination of your entire Friends timeline, @Replies, DMs, or tweets from those nearby, also.  This is IM+'s strongest feature since even if you choose not to use it as your main Twitter client, it can provide timely notifications of relevant tweets.
Anecdotally, I've found IM+'s implementation of finding ""nearby tweets"" the best even amongst its Twitter only competitors on the iPhone such as Echofon, TweetDeck, TwitBird, etc.  In addition, you can easily create a persistent search of tweets so you can catch up on all of the news on American Idol (or Jersey Shore) every time you open the app.
IM+ is less than the best for managing the most commonly accessed Twitter features such as RTs and following, unfortunately.  Most of the functionality is there, but squeezing it into the GUI of an IM app is less than ideal.  For example, the Reply button is pretty small, and you can't follow people directly from the app.  It does have Safari webpage rendering built in which is useful for viewing links and pictures from tweets.
As an IM app, I'd give IM+ 5 stars, but as a Twitter app, balancing it's great push notifications and easy to access search and nearby functionality versus its kludgy implementation of RT and follow yields just 4."

The @grandtweet2 account seems to be the landing area for these ""grandtweets"" which are supposed to be email messages. I really like that I can also tell FB that so-and-so on this network is the same person with a different name on another network.  This app really solves the social problem, bringing it all into one location; best part, it finds my friends for me based on the contacts I have on various networks. Whew."

"5140"	"2257"	"Andrea Raquel"	"SugarFreeCoach"	"4"	"2"	"2010-02-24 07:36:44 UTC"	"After using the Ning network to facilitate several sights for multiple users. I've experienced the process of transfering ownership as well as disabling a site. I've worked with large and small as well as public and private networks. 

Over all Ning is a user friendly and economical solution for a start up network manager. A business owner or association manager can quickly create an almost customized site for free. There are plenty of add-ons and features to enhance the site adding value for members.

The opportunities are in the fees and the member interaction. The fees are a la cart and add up quickly. You will pay a monthly fee for a fully branded site where you control advertising. The biggest gripe I've heard from users is the freedom in which members are able to contact other members across networks. There is an upside and downside. Freedom of networking is always a good thing; however when people take advantage and begin to target other members for spam and phishing scams it reflects negatively on Ning."

"5419"	"2144"	"p6ril"	"p6ril"	"5"	"0"	"2010-03-29 11:41:07 UTC"	"For long I didn't know how to keep track of tweets and links I was interested in on Twitter. Being a geek, I search and read a lot of tutorials on various subjects like jQuery, CSS, HTML or whatever. To start with I used to favorite those tweets but mining the favorites didn't do the job. Then I started storing the corresponding articles on Instapaper and ReaditLater but still wasn't satisfied.

Now I only need to retweet anything I find of interest and if it links to a web resource, it's automatically backed up to my Delicious account where I benefit from the tag structure to easily sort out anything I've tweeted. Packrati.us also works fine with your own tweets and may check your @ replies as well if you ask it to.

The Rat is very active and does the job quietly for you in the background. It's already been improving ever since I discovered the service, and provides useful features to manage how your tweets are backed up to Delicious. This is certainly one of the best services ever I'm so glad I find it ... and best of it all: it's free."

"5438"	"151"	"Joselin Mane"	"JoselinMane"	"4"	"0"	"2010-03-31 10:58:06 UTC"	"I like foursquare for a variety of reasons, that don't necessarily focus on the actual technology. I really like the gaming aspect which I think had a significant impact on early adoption. 

One of the critical elements of any social media tool is it's usage. I think many venues in Boston are missing a great opportunity by not leveraging a Mayorship program. People who are active on foursquare, similar to twitter,  also tend to be active marketers/promoters. 

I also like the fact that they invented the ""check in"" and now almost every geo-location app has incorporated such a simple concept.

There is much more to discuss about this app which is a sign of a great app. 

I would give it 5 stars however as an active user I find that it isn't quite fast enough for me to best leverage it, and it actually slows me down at times. "

 * Stalking = means I follow them, but they do not follow me.

 * Stalkers = means they follow me, but I haven't followed them yet.

I mean, how much of a direct effect is at play? Obviously, Kutcher’s race against CNN and the subsequent mention by Oprah were milestones as far as the San Francisco giant was concerned. The fact remains that many discovered Twitter there, and hopped in just to be in stellar company. These individuals are the ones who will put the Famous Chatter website to splendid use. 

Essentially, through the site it is possible to create a list with these celebrities who tweet and see their updates in a single stream, without noise or distractions of any kind. The way this is achieved is quite simple, as you only have to pick the celebrities one by one from the provided list, add them to a custom list and import it into the relevant categories 

From that point onwards, you will be 
capable of staying abreast of every single development as regards you favorite celebrities that have embraced social media. A straightforward service above all – it showcases one of the facets of Twitter that is most popular, in my opinion this will be the future of twitter to get people on board."

"5844"	"302"	"Mike D"	"acmethunder"	"4"	"2"	"2010-04-22 18:28:05 UTC"	"I got tired of all ugly AIR apps out their, and came across this one.  I was looking for a native Mac app that had all the features of Tweetdeck, and Nambu comes the closest.

It UI fits nicely in the Mac environment, and more importantly for me, is not a resource hog.  It correctly syncs my teitter stream, and in sent items, even inlcudes my posts from twitter.com; as opposed to other clients that only include posts sent from that app.

The conversation view is pretty nice, and shortened URL preview is key showing the domain it leads to.

What Nambu does need is the ability to view users and add followers from the app itself.  Currently, it opens the user's profile in a browser.  And posting to multiple accounts would also be a nice feature as well.

Over all, a clean, simple, and stale app."
"5845"	"302"	"Andy Levy"	"andylevy"	"5"	"2"	"2010-04-22 18:28:49 UTC"	"Even though it's in beta, it's already hands down the best twitter client for Mac, by far. I was a tweetie for mac user, and liked it, but it's now gone from my hard drive. Nambu's ability to track conversations is better implemented than tweetie, and the convenience of having the option to view all your feeds - friends, mentions, searches, DMs, lists - in one column is fantastic. No more switching between columns if you don't want to. (And it's customizable, so, for example, you can choose not to see lists in the ""all"" view.) It's got tons of other features as well (URL previews, photo previews, username auto-complete, etc.), and it's fast as hell. When I used tweetie I would always end up keeping twitter.com open because it updated more quickly - not so with Nambu. And, finally, they're great at responding to user questions @nambucom, which is always nice whether you're dealing with a beta or a final release. If you're not using Nambu, you're seriously missing out."
"5846"	"302"	"Alec R. Hosterman"	"AlecHosterman"	"5"	"1"	"2010-04-22 18:29:07 UTC"	"I've used a variety of other clients but I return to Nambu each and every time. It's stylish, compact, and easy to navigate. In terms of advantages, I like the picture-in-tweet option (it shows up when someone twitpics or yfrog's an image) and auto-resizing of hyperlinks. One of the handiest features is being able to do an @ message and have it auto-fill in the person's username. It's highly customizable and great for someone who runs multiple twitter accounts: clicking on the username of that account automatically generates it from that account, rather than having to manually switch who it comes from. Overall, this is a fantastic application that only gets better with each new update."

"6249"	"2454"	"Claire Wadlington"	"wadlington"	"5"	"1"	"2010-05-08 00:09:27 UTC"	"Easy to use, with fun and original rating system. Developer assumes you actually read all your tweets, and that you might be using this tool to weed out a few very heavy tweeters to see through to the rest of your twitter stream. He calculates Twitter Load Units (TLU's) with the logic that each takes 1 second to process, and that 1661 TLUs costs you 1 day a year of reading twitter. He then compares your total Weekly TLU's to frequent tweeter @scobleizer (as in how many times you could follow @scobleizer and get as many tweets as you are getting).   I used the info to unfollow a few heavy tweeters whose posts weren't things I regularly read - and left some others whose stuff I like."
"6250"	"1821"	"Andrew Puckett"	"okpuck"	"5"	"0"	"2010-05-08 02:07:18 UTC"	"Best Twitter app I have ever used :D The lack of native Push Notifications is more than made up for with Boxcar running alongside."

"6386"	"1269"	"Jesus Nieves"	"TheGeeZus"	"5"	"0"	"2010-05-14 03:29:37 UTC"	"Twixtreme - A Underrated Twitter Client

During September 2009, I was searching the internet with Google about alternatives to quench my addición with Twitter, but I had a problem at that time had a Blackberry Curve 8330.. I also had two free alternatives that already had been used at the time.

   1. TwitterBerry –not a bad application and was obviously created to match perfectly with the Blackberry, erm sorry, been attempted, because the 2 versions I had (the last one before you change the name and before) always had the problem I warning light lit and from the phone to vibrate at random times. She also became tedious to not update the stream and sometimes my Logear differences were easily 5 to 6 hours and not get me wrong, I love to read the tweets of my friends but it became tedious to read things that had happened and that the program maxime encouraged the more ascended to the most recent.

   2. ÜberTwitter – actually I thought my search was over, but something I never liked is that the makers of UT have a private server on which nobody has access and did not like that every time he took out picture, the picture stays on that server until the end of time. The worst thing you could do is make the program a free version Adware Adware and had to pay. I don't have any problems they want to do and make money from their sweat, but I feel like my phone that will spread of cookies and temporary files that are used to record commercials and I've had problems with programs that have advertising applications of ""Partners"" business ...

 I was about to give up, when by chance I found a blog talking about a Twitter client that does not suck (A Twitter Client That Does not Suck).  When I saw it, I began to have puppy's eyes to see that if a client was designed by the company Blackberry Xtreme Labs called Twixtreme. Not only am I glad it was free, I loved that did not have ads or anything like that and everything seems indicate that this will be their winning formula.


Without further ado, let's talk about what we offer:
\ First of all, responding to my complaints from TwitterBerry, Twixtreme, is quite fast in its interface. The speed of recording and extracting tweets of your account is quite fast, even with people who use Blackberry with EDGE signal (* cough, cough ... .*).

  Apart from the rapid connection, you have the option to update your own tweets stream or the program do it automatically.
Solving my photos ÜberTwitter complaint, and that a couple of people will like is that Twixtreme and tune your account Twitpic, which means you control directly your photos.

Creating Tweets is another cool little walk well. Apart from Tweets and see your friends' Twixtreme lets you see the latest trends and also look into Twitter, Mark favorite, ReTweet and see answers and references.  I must admit that if I started using it, noticed that the graph of the blue bird, can be a bit annoying at first, but my saying that if it does not, then something bad happens.
 
Why is the title of the article is well then?
  Answer: Even so with the advantages of Twixtreme note, it seems that people are resisting the possibility ÜberTwitter's reign began to crumble when they decided to put Adware and there are many contenders for the kingship. Some people are complaints to the program and I say it is people coming Multi-Client Networks. I do not like the Multi-Networks, I say that the more you use a self-service (Example: Facebook -> Facebook For Blackberry) better enjoy it. Twixtreme why I say that will keep singing.

"6545"	"1128"	"myatu"	"myatu"	"2"	"0"	"2010-05-19 14:02:19 UTC"	"Brizzly does not work well with the Opera browsers. 

Issues such as the inability to click on saved searches or lists, increasingly slower performance the longer you use it and various others make it less appealing to Opera users. 

The company is well aware of the issues, however they have assumed that Opera does not have a large enough market share and therefore it isn't worth their while to fix Brizzly. Instead they suggest to use a different browser.

On the positive side is that the interface has a nice, easy to use layout and the ""mute"" option and using DM a la IM are nice features.

Given the lack of company interest for Opera users and the inability to use certain features, I give it a 2 star rating."

"6801"	"1405"	"rachida chic"	"rachida_chic"	"3"	"0"	"2010-06-03 03:21:54 UTC"	"TweetReach est un outil de recherche pour Twitter qui permet d'analyser le nombre de personnes ayant vue une information. Il est possible de faire des recherches par rapport à un mot clef, un nom d'utilisateur ou un hastag.

Afin d'être pertinent TweetReach cumul la recherche dans différents moteurs et analyse les amis communs entre les utilisateurs. Grace à cela vous avez une estimation plus précise du nombre de personnes ayant pu voir votre information.

Le calcul se fait sur les 50 derniers tweets (l'analyse complète est payante), mais c'est déjà très intéressant sur 50 tweets.

Les informations obtenues en 2 mots :

    * La repartions entre tweet, retweet et reply d'une information tweetée
    * La liste des personnes ayant contribué à la propagation de l'information avec le nombre de vues qu'elles ont apportées.
   bonne app merci ♥
"

"6949"	"2434"	"Joshua Novick"	"jnovick"	""	"1"	"2010-06-14 18:16:18 UTC"	"Really interesting way to find new users to follow. The idea is quite cleaver. Users are classified by the number of times they are included in a list with a specific tag. That is, if a user has been tagged in 5 lists that have to di with ""marketing"" and is from Paraguay he will be listed as an expert in marketing in Paraguay. His position in the ranking ""marketing in Paraguay"" has to do with how many times he has been tagged in ""marketing""  in comparison to other users that have also meen ""tagged"" in lists ""marrketing"". The idea is you are how other twitter users see you, not how you see yourself.
"

PROS:
*3 months of data is available for free.
*Easy to compare up to 2 other users, AKA competitors.
*Weekly digest is emailed weekly.

CONS:
*The data is not 100% up to date, but it is accurate on average.
*I wish more than 3 months of data was available but I guess that's what the premium paid service is for.
*I wish that I can print the graphs. Some of the graphs can be saved as a picture file but not downloaded as a data or excel file.
*I wish it shared not only the total gain or loss in a day, but also the absolute number gained AND lossed separately. (FYI, Qwitter.com is another tool, not perfect, but still useful)

I wonder if TwitterCounter has other competitors..."

"7396"	"3048"	"Raul Colon"	"rj_c"	"5"	"0"	"2010-07-24 15:26:31 UTC"	"I was able to use FollowFriday.com as a beta tester and was initially impressed. I found many benefits to the blog. The most practical one I Found is the creation of lists of the people that sent a #followfriday to a user and the option to send them a default tweet thanking (so you don’t forget). 

Other features are: 
oVery balanced front page with a Ranking of the user with the most mentions including the #FollowFriday hashtag. 
oRanking by Country – is unique because it allows people to view who in their country received the most #FollowFriday . 
oRanking by Language – Same as the Ranking by Country it gives you an idea on how was given the most #FollowFriday by Language
oRanking by Verified – Separates the rest of twitter with those very privileged and validated verified accounts which are very well know users, companies, or celebrities. 
oIt limits users who make more than 50 recommendations which can be used to get a #FollowFriday in return.
oWidgets – as of right now it allows you to create a Widget for your blog or website with any selected user. 
oVery simple FAQ’s section which helps understand the process of the ranking of users.
On the User Panel
oRecommend a user and give them a #FollowFriday directly from the Followfriday.com
oFollow the user directly. 
oShare the information on how many recommendations the user received. 
oCreate a list of the people recommending the user or the user recommended.
oNew followers from #followfriday
oHow many recommendations where received on previous Fridays. 
oAn option to grab the Widget for the user. 
oA graph depicting the #FollowFriday mentions from previous weeks.

Overall I am completely impressed by the first launch of Followfriday.com and I can wait to experience the other features that will be added to the application.
"

"7464"	"2936"	"ErrolCoder"	"ErrolCoder"	"5"	"0"	"2010-07-31 23:12:21 UTC"	"For 10 years I have contributed on a number of different question/answer sites. Up to 5 years ago most people were active on forum based websites which made the previous question sites quite active, but  now-a-days the world is all about fast and speed. The natural progression for these kinds of sites required adaption to applications such as Twitter. Well, the developers of Wondir.com were on the ball with this one.

Using the fast paced instant transmissions of content all over the net using Twitter, they have opened up the ability for anyone; consumer researchers, public poll services, teachers, students, anyone to post a question using Twitter or on the Replyz.com site itself. Anyone, may then join in and answer the questions they want. You can filter the thousands of questions that come in hourly by the Topics you like to focus on, whether it is Gaming, Computers, a specific TV show, pretty much anything you want. You can then sit back every day, take a few moments to either post your own questions, or answer questions you see.

Replyz is the bold first of its kind to come along and really take the fast paced net by the horns and bring about useful tool that can really change how we research and find answers, using the knowledge and expertise of the people themselves.

"7488"	"580"	"Mark Sherman"	"brazentone"	"5"	"0"	"2010-08-04 12:36:36 UTC"	"The best twitter client I have ever used. "7489"	"1923"	"Mark Sherman"	"brazentone"	"4"	"0"	"2010-08-04 12:51:15 UTC"	"(Android) Better than the stock twitter app for features, but many operations take some menu digging. TweetCaster allows you to view lists very easily, but you can't make them the default view. To get to a list you want to see, it can be up to 3 menu items deep. Sometimes it can't load data from a list. It will suddenly stop working and just as suddenly return.
It handles multiple accounts, but that should be considered a standard feature. 
The ""Select View"" menu changes the app's whole context, which is a cool way to handle trends, searches, and other views. I think lists should be moved into the top-level views menu, and not hidden within the accounts view.
Clicking on a link or a person's name in a tweet is not very slick. Click on a tweet in any view and you get a (possibly large) pop-up menu listing the links, usernames, and other actions you can do with it. Click the link in that menu and then it sends you to the android pop-up of ""what program do you want to open it with?"" and then you can see your link. It wouldn't be so bad if the menu item descriptions were a little clearer.
I have no performance issues on a Nexus One. Overall pretty solid. UI concepts are a little divided, but you can figure it out pretty quickly."

"7498"	"3023"	"Lloyd Gofton"	"Liberatelloyd"	"5"	"0"	"2010-08-05 08:28:43 UTC"	"So, what’s the difference between Tweasier and the other Twitter management applications? Surely Chris has missed the boat and been beaten to the punch by other Twitter clients? Well, no, Tweasier is much more than a client. Tweasier’s brilliance is in the features it offers, and specifically the analytics suite.

Yes, i know there are other free Twitter analytics packages, but Tweasier is well…easier. It’s an all in one package, and the Tweasier team has obviously put a lot of thought into exactly what the user wants from their Twitter application, including simple but effective search and suggestions features.

Take my advice, when you go to Tweasier, check out the Analytics package, and have a play. I think it’s a real triumph of useful data displayed in a simple and readable format. The dashboard offers 30 different types of stats, including network features that show who of your followers is most influential. Some stats can also be exported, which makes my life so much easier!

Tweasier is currently in Beta and i’m sure it will improve, but it’s already excellent, and although i’m sure the last few weeks before launch have been tough for Chris and his team, he can rest assured that it’s been worth it. I’ve already shown the package to a few clients and they all love it.

Well done guys!"

We use Tweasier to see who are the most influential users in our network and to stay up to date with what is happening in our Twitter account. I really like the activity feed that presents all of the latest activity from your Twitter account similar to the Facebook newsfeed. However, one of the most important features is probably the email digests as this can help when you are on the road as it means you don’t have to log in and out of twitter it all arrives on your mobile. I think the interface could be better and I know that the guys are upgrading the statistics sections but all in all I think Tweasier is a useful Twitter application if you use Twitter for business and you are looking to save time."

"7663"	"3121"	"cori schlegel"	"cori"	"1"	"0"	"2010-08-18 16:52:16 UTC"	"I didn't initially try this out because there was no auto-tweet opt-out or notification and it was pretty obvious from my twitter stream that it was auto-tweeting results. The source and meaning of the data is unclear, with no additional information available, and the explanation is highly subjective; mine says: ""You are doing well on Twitter, you are keeping up with your Tweets but could still do better."" What does that even mean? What signifies ""keeping up"" and what would make it ""better""?

All in all this app seems like little more than a Twitter API ""Hello World"" and I suspect the only reason it's got so much traction is because of the initial auto-tweet setup, so the developer seems to have gotten his traction from abusing the twitter ecosystem, for that a -1."
"7664"	"3121"	"Tim Adams"	"tadams_InMind"	"4"	"0"	"2010-08-18 17:18:21 UTC"	"I thought it was interesting and yes - didn't really understand the score but I assume it is based on how many people in your network (followers) and the number of tweets you send out (received in your network). Nothing to cheer about but interesting just the same!

"7680"	"2476"	"Albert Willis"	"alwillis"	"3"	"0"	"2010-08-20 05:45:06 UTC"	"Does pretty much everything you'd want a Twitter client to do, with the added bonus of being Mac OS X-native. Perhaps the best feature is being able to create tabs that track the tweets of particular followers or a Twitter list. Tabs can also show tweets by keyword or regular expressions if that's how you roll. Each custom tab can have it's own set of alerts. But even with a bunch of tab alerts defined, there's a global Silent Mode that mutes them until you feel like turning them back on.

YoruFukurou has three display modes for tweets which can be helpful when screen real estate is an issue. It also has the super-useful auto completion of Twitter IDs, which is handy when referencing people you don't tweet that often. 


And there are a bunch of other features; if you're a Twitter tinkerer on a Mac, this is the client for you.

A couple of issues though: it doesn't support as many image services as some clients. For example, I use img.ly, but YoruFukurou doesn't support it. Uploading images is a little clunky; unlike most Twitter clients, you have to upload the picture first, then create the tweet that goes with it. The user interface takes some getting used to, especially if you're used to Tweetie or Twitterrific for the Mac, which have minimalist interfaces. And currently, you can only manage one Twitter account using YoruFukurou. I'm using it for my personal account and Tweetie for Mac to manage the others. There's also no Applescript or Automator support if you're looking to automate some of your tweeting.

YoruFukurou ('NightOwl' in English) is a Japanese Twitter client, but there's English documentation at http://sites.google.com/site/yorufukurou/home-en. There are versions for both Mac OS X 10.5 Leopard and 10.6 Snow Leopard.
"

"7761"	"3151"	"Kathy Shaidle"	"kshaidle"	""	"2"	"2010-08-29 22:56:51 UTC"	"I used TweetDeck for a long time, but switched to MarketMeSuite a while ago and never looked back.

Why? Well, the World Cup was the last straw for me :-) TweetDeck kept crashing, whereas MarketMeSuite didn't fail once. 

MarketMeSuite also lets you manage Twitter and Facebook from one place; helps put Ping.fm and RSS to work for you, offers tweet scheduling, follow/unfollow management and other features that have become must-haves with any Twitter client software or app.

However, MarketMeSuite does one thing none of the other apps can: it lets you ""brand"" the ""via"" line at the very end of every tweet. Usually that line will say ""via TweetDeck"" or ""via the web."" Why not claim that precious online real estate and link juice for yourself?

I've noticed a significant increase in blog traffic since branding my tweets with MMS. 

Highly recommended."

"7867"	"2919"	"Ed Butler"	"ej_butler"	"4"	"1"	"2010-09-12 09:59:58 UTC"	"There comes a time for most Twitter users when the sheer volume of tweets is too much to keep up with.  FriendTrend is something that should help remedy this situation.
 
FriendTrend allows a Twitter user to identify the top 100 ""trends"" in the tweets of other Twitter users that they are following over various lengths of time (1000 tweets, 12 hours, 6 hours and 1 hour).
 
Trends can be displayed using hashtags or words.  I have found that the trends displayed using hashtags are more accurate than trends displayed using words.

User Interface is easy enough to navigate - tap on one of the listed trending topics and all related tweets will be displayed.
 
Tap on one of the individual tweets listed and three buttons will be displayed - ""Open Link"", ""Reply"" and ""Retweet"".

The ""Retweet"" option opens up a new ""reply"" window and allows the original tweet to be edited prior to sending.

It's also possible to view the unfiltered tweet stream by tapping on 'All Tweets'
 
Overall, not a bad App for the price but I'd see it as being a companion App to your main Twitter App rather than a replacement."

Dear all,

We've been working relentlessly for the last 2 years to help our users better manage their contacts and conversation history. Unfortunately, today, we are announcing some important changes that will impact all current users.

Starting January 31st, we will be phasing out the Silentale service and, in its place, we'll unveil SocialReplay, a time machine for social media accounts.

What this means for current users
Effective January 31st, your Silentale account will cease to be updated. You will still have access to your account and data until February 14th. After this date, your data will be irrevocably deleted.

What this means for Premium users
Your data will be preserved 60 days beyond February 14th. Please contact us to arrange for downloading your archive.

What this means for new users
As of today, signup for new accounts has been suspended.

If you have any questions, please send them to support@silentale.com.

Laurent Féral-Pierssens
& the Silentale team
January 24, 2011 "

In the newest updated @RovioMobile is adding a Giant Eagle bird that when called upon destroys EVERYTHING he touches.  This game is THE most addicting game I have ever played and also it allows you to tweet your score and compete against your friends scores.  MUST HAVE!!!"

Bien plus qu’un agrégateur de réseaux sociaux ou de services de chat, Yoono propose à l’utilisateur d’interagir directement avec ses contacts en un lieu unique.

L’utilisateur reste ainsi informé en permanence des activités de ses amis et relations et peut dialoguer avec eux par le canal de son choix, en restant à l’intérieur de Yoono. Cet outil est disponible à la fois sous forme d’extension pour firefox et d’application pour votre desktop (Windows, Mac OS et Linux).

Yoono vous permet ainsi de garder sous le coude la quasi totalité de vos services numériques dans une interface unifiée, qui peut aussi se faire discrète (un unique bouton fait apparaître ou disparaître yoono), qu’il s’agisse de réseaux sociaux, messageries instantanées, flux rss, photos flickr, etc.

Vous pourrez également rajouter des onglets pour vos webmails, votre musique, le service Découverte, ou Web Notes qui vous permet de sauvegarder des morceaux de pages web (un compte yoono est cependant requis pour cette dernière fonction).

Nous vous laissons le soin de découvrir tous les petits plus de chacun des outils intégrés à Yoono, en le recommandant à tout ceux qui sont en permanence sur leur navigateur et qui ont besoin de gérer leur vie sociale virtuelle en permanence, ce pour quoi Yoono est un redoutable outil."

    * Des API permettent de personnaliser l’expérience de l’utilisateur directement dans son feedly.

"7975"	"3140"	"Eric Miltsch"	"emiltsch"	"5"	"0"	"2010-09-24 05:00:06 UTC"	"Philo is quickly making a name for itself within the activity based check in segment and their goal of making TV social.

Philo gives you and your friends new ways of exploring television. 
Earn points and unlock awards for watching buzz-worthy shows.

Its quite simple. Philo’s goal is to help you:

Tune in to TV shows
Share what you’re watching
Gossip with friends about tv
What I like about Philo, besides the easy to use interface and logical processes, is the ability to  find shows in real-time based on your location and TV services. Even if you don’t want to tune-in, the app can be your TV guide. May as well play along for the chance to win something. TV doesn’t need to be boring.

Tuning in via the schedule also helps prevent users from gaming the system for the sake of unlocking badges and points – like some of the activity seen on Philo’s competitor Miso.

Philo’s Marketing Manager Christopher Sanson does a nice job engaging users & creating a personal connection to an otherwise impersonal application. One recent promotion for the season finale of Futurama involved tuning-in via the app. Doing so gave you a chance to win prizes such as bobblehead dolls and an XBOX. Another early advantage for Philo.

Philo’s badge designs are well done; extra points for making a badge with Boba Fett on it. Points are also earned with each tune in and it appears that one can earn credits – although I’m not sure how that’s done other tuning-in. Safe bet that future versions will involve even more interactivity and promotional tie-ins.

Not sure if the app’s namesake was influenced by the ancient Jewish Philosopher Philo and his fondness of order and knowledge, or if it was simply chosen for Christopher’s fondness of Philo Beddo in Every Which Way But Loose. I’m guessing it’s from Philo Farnsworth, the famous inventor responsible for creating the technology which lets us view images on TV."

And, on top of all this, they have a full-function iPhone app - looking now into how these two can be used in concert between desktop and mobile. Great compare/contrast vs Tweetdeck."

Works great for automated scripts and/or command-line tweeting."

"8123"	"646"	"Eric Andersen"	"eric_andersen"	"5"	"0"	"2010-10-12 03:42:30 UTC"	"The incredible thing about Tweetstats is it's ability to look back across your entire history on Twitter (or at least the past two years) and perform various calculations across that entire time-frame. Wondering about your Twitter usage trends over the past two years? What Twitter clients you've used most? Who you @reply the most? What hour of the day or day of the week during which you tweet the most? What hashtags or words you've used most in your tweets? Other tools perform calculations like this over a recent time period - say a week or a month - but Tweetstats looks at this over a much longer time-frame, making it ideal to see long-term patterns and trends."

"8127"	"2702"	"Lionel Tilmont  ♝"	"vonbrucken"	"5"	"0"	"2010-10-12 13:42:26 UTC"	"I really like this application that I have been using for weeks. Though it is still in alpha stage it is really robust and have been widely adopted by the Twitter community. It is pretty easy to sign-up via OAuth using your Twitter or your Facebook account, once you're done you just have to create your newspaper and here you have three options :
• create a paper based on a Twitter account name and its followers
• create a paper based on a Twitter #tag
• create a paper based on a Twitter list 
The newspaper will be updated every 24 hours and you have the choice of either promoting it automatically or manually. If you chose the later, you can receive email alerts when the new edition is ready.
Attention you can create only 10 newspaper, and the only papers that you will be able to delete will be the one based on your twitter list. I highly recommend it because it allows you to keep up with your different interests and at the same time to discover new Twitter accounts via their Top Stories feature .

Once your  limit of 10 newspapers has been reached, you may also have the possibility to join them. But you will have to convince them !"

I should mention that Favstar recently added RTs along with favorites - providing a more holistic view of interest in a tweet.

But what's really amazing about Favstar are it's two other dimensions:
1) Favstar is pretty much the keeper of funny on Twitter - their leaderboard and the @favstar100 and @favstar50 accounts keep track of some of the funniest and most interesting tweets on Twitter. And of course they have in iPhone app, Favit, which lets you peruse these tweets.
2) With a paid account, you can be notified when your tweets receive various levels of favorites. This lets you know in real-time when a particular tweet has suddenly become popular rather than you having to the site. This can be done via email or via a tweet - very useful!"

This is a perfect application to justify Twitter not only as fun, but as a very useful application for everyone. It also coaxes you to ""clean up,"" your ""Followed"" list and concentrate on specific categories of people you follow, since an unorganized ""Followed"" list generates an unorganized ""newspaper."" In days gone by, people said, ""garbage in, garbage out."" Works best with upwards of 500 ""Followed"" people in your Twitter feed.

The company is organized through a University in French speaking Switzerland, so you can imagine it runs very well, like a Swiss clock. Sometimes the ""clock"" seems a bit awry, but I guess they feel the world runs on Swiss time, not US time zones, but that's ok for such a valuable resource."

"8330"	"2519"	"Lionel Tilmont  ♝"	"vonbrucken"	"5"	"1"	"2010-10-30 10:48:16 UTC"	"Pretty innovative ,I have tested the Firefox extension and the bookmarlet for Chrome.Not really a fan of bookmarklets but for the time being that will do !
This application works on two different and complementary levels. On the first one, it acts as a simple tweet button with the ability to add a concise comment. Your tweet will be then sent in the public timeline for everyone to read.  But it is the second layer that is important because  the link you've shared can be the starting point of a threaded conversation . 
You just have to choose your recipients and a direct message will be sent to them along with a link to your private thread hosted on Bccth.is website .
At the moment I experience difficulties to browse recipients because it seems that the system is  based on real names instead of Twitter usernames. As Subtextual started as an email application that pretty much makes sense. But still,  I hope they will take the more informal Twitter context into consideration and offer username browsing.
I am pretty impressed nonetheless and literally longing for a  Chrome extension !"

"8341"	"1572"	"Occupy The House"	"OccupytheHouse"	"5"	"0"	"2010-11-02 06:28:25 UTC"	"
   I used Shared Minds for about five minutes earlier today and promptly jettisoned TweetDeck. 


    I really like how fast Shared Minds is. The navigation panel is tidy and easy to handle - it isn't a deficit to lose the multiple columns of TweetDeck when this is how you move between the various tweet streams. The choice of default, column view, or list for displaying tweets is very powerful - much better to have a scrollable list of 150 tweets, one per line, than the too narrow TweetDeck columns. The search function provides graphical access to the query options - it's the best I've seen for that sort of work. So far I'm deeply unimpressed by the preview pane, which is used to view the details of an account, but it's not a common thing for me to use and like everything else in Shared Minds it's very simple to recover the screen space by dismissing it. 

   Having used it for all of twelve hours these are things that either the program could do better, or that I've not caught on to how to handle.

 1. How do I make a new list? It's not in the 'add a user to a list' popup, which is in the right place and very slick to use for pre-existing lists.

2. How do I see another user's lists? And then follow them?

3. Is there help for the filter option? The way it's positioned makes me suspect it's very powerful, but I'm at a loss for what to do with it.


   This program feels not quite finished, and even so it kicks the competition all over the Twitterverse. Give it a try and you'll likely stick to it.

"

I'd recommend this project for young developers to get involved in. It's well structured and documented and if you're willing to sit down for a few hours and understand the code there's a lot you can do with it."

It's an amazing product already -- and it's just in beta at the moment. I can't wait to see the future enhancements.

"8457"	"1110"	"Lionel Tilmont  ♝"	"vonbrucken"	"5"	"0"	"2010-11-15 12:39:55 UTC"	"
I have been using Yoono on Firefox for a long time and more recently on Chrome . As I had to re-install it on my Canary Built I thought I could drop a few lines about it. 
With all the noise surrounding the introduction of RockMelt, people must be aware of this really useful application which supports much more services (I used it mainly to monitor my myspace music pages ) and more importantly that is not linked to a specific web browser. If you are more into desktop application then it is fine as Yoono comes also in that flavour. 
It will definitively satisfy most of the needs and on the media side it can upload directly to  Yfrog, MySites and Plixi (formerly TweetPhoto ) .
** Note about the Chrome beta version : 
There is two ways of displaying Yoono : in tab or in sidebar mode. My only complain here is that I would have liked the sidebar to be integrated à la Firefox instead of having a floating window or at least  for it to be  be magnetised to the browser window. Not a big set-back though if you consider the productivity gain on single screen workstations ."

With all the noise surrounding the introduction of RockMelt, people must be aware of this really useful application which supports much more services (I used it mainly to monitor my myspace music pages ) and more importantly that is not linked to a specific web browser. If you are more into desktop application then it is fine as Yoono comes also in that flavour. 
It will definitively satisfy most of the needs and on the media side it can upload directly to Yfrog, MySites and Plixi (formerly TweetPhoto ) . 
** Note about the Chrome beta version : 
There is two ways of displaying Yoono : in tab or in sidebar mode. My only complain here is that I would have liked the sidebar to be integrated à la Firefox instead of having a floating window or at least for it to be be magnetised to the browser window. Not a big set-back though if you consider the productivity gain on single screen workstations ."

"8582"	"3271"	"Mallory Pickard"	"MissMallibu"	"5"	"0"	"2010-11-29 23:04:43 UTC"	"The app serves as a user-friendly (user-loving, even) mobile Tumblr that enables users to share snapshots of their worlds through custom filters.  The effects range from vintage-drenched X-Pro II to brooding, noir Gotham to Apollo, a washed out Milky Way stratiform that looks great layered over night shots and befuddled dog faces.

Equally impressive is the subtly addictive social feature.  Instagram isn't a preemptive social network, and yet I find myself opening the app more and more just to browse and ""like"" photos, check updates, browse through users who like the same photos as me, follow new people-- all the simple social networking habits that made Twitter and Tumblr so successful.

Key extras: 
A simple privacy toggle gives you the option of authorizing followers before they can view your photos.  

You can quickly find friends from your iPhone contacts, Facebook, and Twitter accounts.  

You have the option of syncing with Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr, Flickr, and even Foursquare, but the real UX genius here is in the individual on/off toggle features for each platform.  Users are given the ability to choose which of their social networks best suits the snapshot in question, and there's also the option to simply let the photo live on Instagram.  Choice is beauty.

The only seemingly missing feature is an archive for your previous Likes to collect.  But in the context of a moment-driven app such as Instagram, this may just translate to paradoxical mobile baggage-- or a nice premium feature in the future."

My issue is the way the ads refresh makes my timeline move around which is very distracting when I am interacting with it.
