"8670"	"3543"	"Ryan Plinske"	"plinske"	"5"	"1"	"2010-12-08 22:21:28 UTC"	"I initially started using this on my iPhone 4 and iPad with much anticipation for the Mac version, since after all, Apple is 'Back to the Mac' and well @reederapp is 'Bringing RSS feeds back from the dead'. @reederapp syncs with your @google reader account and allows you to read all of your RSS feeds beautifully.  Inside @reederapp you can share articles via @delicious @zootool @instapaper @twitter @facebook @pinboardIN & @readitlater.  The UI of this app across all platforms is simply outstanding.

iPhone Version:
The one that started it all and now the little brother to the iPad & Mac versions.  When you open up @reederapp you will see 4 icons on the bottom toolbar (starred, unread, & all items) and refresh.  The app also uses the RSS fav icons to distinguish the feeds even smoother.  If you click on one of the feeds you will see a list of all the articles and have the option to swipe it left (star the article) or right (mark as read).  

iPad Version:
Very similar to my iPhone description yet this time they've taken full advantage of the iPads beautiful screen.  The RSS feeds are now in a grid display with slightly bigger fav icons that look amazing.  On the left is the toolbar where everything happens much similar to the iPhone version.

Mac Version:
The @reederapp for mac is now in beta draft 4 but don't let the 'beta' part scare you away.  They have significantly changed the app with each update for better performance.  The mac version does the exact same thing as the iPad and iPhone version but may have just included the best feature for a mac app.  The latest update included mouse gestures which allow you to use your Magic Mouse or Magic Trackpad with @reederapp.  This is simply pure genius!

If you haven't checked out @reederapp then what the heck are you waiting for... GET THIS APP NOW!!!"

"8697"	"1421"	"Naveen Dittakavi"	"navditt"	"5"	"0"	"2010-12-13 21:12:09 UTC"	"Tweetymail is so, so helpful! Here are the ways I've found it invaluable:

Traveling: I travel abroad a lot and although I buy a international roaming data plan for my iPhone, I don't use Twitter for iPhone, I use tweetymail. Why? Because I simply want to post something to twitter without launching the Twitter app which consumes a LOT of data.

Photos: The iPhone doesn't let you publish photos and video unless you launch a Twitter app, select the photo, upload it, and finally confirm the post. Instead of all that nonsense, just choose the photo from your camera library and email it to Tweetymail, voila it's up.

Replies and Auto keyword search: I use Google Alerts heavily for my business and to monitor personal references. Tweetymail monitors the twitterverse for me for the keywords that are important to me. When any of my accounts are @replied or if any of my keywords are mentioned, I receive an email digest with the details. From the digest I can immediately reply and get involved in the conversation without delay.

It's an amazing service, worth paying for!"

The “Follow Friday” suggestions are a neat little add on too.


I just started to try out the “Follow Builder” feature, and so far it has been fun to play around with the advanced settings to create a solid list of people I may wish to follow based on key terms, min/max followers, and by time they have tweeted/etc. I am still messing with this though and hope to get it even more efficient for my use.


While I haven’t yet requested or used any reports, I do like the fact that they are there, and that the Crowdbooster team is making it an option to tell them what you are looking for specifically, and see if they can create reports for you with that data exclusively for your needs. 


I hope everyone gets a chance to check out Crowdbooster, and look forward to hearing the thoughts, and andy tips or tricks, of others!

"8961"	"3467"	"Josh Nekrep"	"joshnekrep"	"4"	"0"	"2011-01-16 03:24:15 UTC"	"This is, perhaps, the nicest, cleanest, AND most practical way of using Hootsuite.  I have for some time now made good use of the web client as well as the iPhone app for Hootsuite.  However, when I first loaded up Hootsuite for iPad I was *stunned*.  It is a remarkably beautiful environment, it works in both Portrait and Landscape mode, and automatically imports your streams when you first log in (assuming you've already created some).  

The only thing holding me back from giving this app 5 stars is that, like all current Hootsuite platforms, it's grossly lacking in its ability to help you manage lists and deal with new followers, and it can sometimes be difficult to follow conversations (clicking on a tweet does not show you any replies to that tweet, for instance).  This isn't a failing of the iPad app, so much as a shortcoming of Hootsuite in general.  

Overall, the iPad app has become my favorite Hootsuite environment.  I'd definitely recommend it!

"8962"	"3123"	"Jessica Merrell"	"blogging4jobs"	""	"0"	"2011-01-16 04:28:35 UTC"	"The website is no longer active.  It takes you to a Godaddy page.  "
"8963"	"3617"	"Kevin Marks"	"kevinmarks"	"1"	"-1"	"2011-01-16 09:33:26 UTC"	"I've been trying to use Twitter For Mac, but it misses so many things it's painful.

1. It doesn't have a box to type tweets in. Let me say that again. You have to hit Command-N or click on the tiny light grey on dark grey bird in the bottom corner to post anything. Yes, a lot of people use twitter as a mostly read-only experience, but encouraging them to say something back would be considered a good thing by most people.

2. The typography is pitiful. Type is 30% between black and white, with a spindly font choice that submerges itself into background illegibility. Hashtags are deliberately washed out to 70% white, encouraging you to ignore them and not implying clickability in any way. The timestamps are 90% white. Evanescence is clearly the design goal here. Put this app in the background, and ignore it forever.

3. It feels slow. Clicking on the woefully small profile icons yields a pulsing circle for what seems ages, compared to the snappy response of classic twitter web (New Twitter has a similar lag). Clicking on the profile pictures pops up the full-zize version just after you clicked something else assuming it was broken.

4. No way to find people.

5. Retweeting takes three clicks. Click the retweet button, choose whether to amplify or quote, then an 'are you sure?' dialog that even the UI team from Windows 3.1 would have rejected. 

6. DM's. Hides them well. Perhaps a small mercy, when compared to how both Brizzly and Twitter For Android make DM's a huge deal until you've read them in their particular client. It also abbreviates them to fit a layout, until you click.

7. What he said about confusing UI transitions and photos: http://www.kickerstudio.com/blog/2011/01/the-trouble-with-tweetie-2-twitter-mac-client/
"

"9129"	"3672"	"ljevanspp"	"ljevanspp"	""	"0"	"2011-01-28 10:24:05 UTC"	"NM Incite offers more than than just a dashboard, however. I'm one of the UK team, and actually we spend most of our time using the metrics to build brand/product/consumer insight for our clients in a similar way you might use a focus group, or perhaps a round of semi-structured interviews. I sometimes think that it's helpful to think of the the world of consumer generated media as a huge, free, online focus group. 

The difficulty in managing what this means for your brand lies, therefore, in gathering all of the truly relevant information- or as much as you are able- coding and classifying it in a helpful way around the business need, and then applying classic qualitative techniques to build insights of value from a foundation of unpredictable data that is actually robust. Hmmm... can you tell I'm a researcher?! This is the sort of thing that gets me really excited about the work we do, and the value of listening to natural, spontaneously generated (and not survey driven) commentary.

Yes, we do have a world class dashboard offering, but actually what is much more helpful for our clients is the analysis and the partnership that we can also provide through our customised research and our dashboard support services. So please don't think of us just as a tool- that would be dismissing the huge value of our McKinsey tie-in too. :)"

"9255"	"1690"	"Nick Rovisa"	"NickRovisa"	"4"	"0"	"2011-02-12 22:04:29 UTC"	"I've tried a few different 3rd party apps, but Echofon is by far my favorite. It's the perfect client: easy to use, clean & simple UI, supports most of the features you want/need in a client and, best of all, it's not overwhelming like some of the other apps I've used (ahem, tweetdeck). The only gripe I have with it (which is why I went with 4 and not 5 stars) is the fact that you cannot see who retweeted you. In order to see who's retweeted you in Echofon, you either have to sign up with a service such as @formulists (which will list everyone that has retweeted you) or you have to open each retweet in the browser.

Once this functionality is built right into Echofon, it will be a perfect 5 and I'll no longer need to access Twitter in the browser again. This is in no way a deal breaker though, I use Echofon on my mac and iPhone, and Echofon only.

The orientation piece is great for brands wanting to create an experience for users. In addition to that experience are user-generated content, like tips and the ability for users to add to the challenges. Currently, a very small group of people use tools like this to 'connect,' making the time and financial investment as a brand tricky, unless you just want to reach out to a niche of your market and/or spend the time to educate and inspire behavior change. It will be fun to watch the LBS space grow in the next few years. "

"9603"	"3880"	"Foundation Center"	"fdncenter"	"5"	"0"	"2011-04-14 22:31:35 UTC"	"Thrive is simple, reliable, and beyond user-friendly.  I schedule all of our updates through Thrive and have never received a dreaded ""Unable to Deliver: Twitter API Returned an Error"" or met an issue that the Small Act team has not had an answer or been able to resolve.  Thrive stores all of the interactions I have with people on Twitter, making it easy to recognize those who are interested in specific types of content, others who are general brand champions, or the few who are just occasional RTers.  This is invaluable in cultivating relationships with people online in a meaningful ""come to our events"" and ""help us spread the word about [X]"" kind of way.  Thrive makes activating your supporter base much simpler and much easier.  

Thrive's reporting system makes visualizing growth in terms of followers, impact, and interactivity (click-throughs, RTs, etc.) both quantifiable and easily explainable to supervisors and key stake-holders.  It's also tremendously gratifying to graphically see your impact in social media (whereas numbers often lack that emotional connection).

Finally, Thrive is frequently updated with new features that improve the overall experience, and that are driven by the customers themselves (that's right, your feedback actually COUNTS to Small Act).  And each time Facebook or Twitter change their features, Thrive is also updated to incorporate the change, and in some cases, even improve upon it (ask them about the Facebook Custom Action Links).  Highly recommend not only the Thrive software, but also working with the awesome folks who support it.  5 stars.   "

"9716"	"3902"	"Kim Sherrell"	"kim"	"4"	"0"	"2011-05-06 18:24:34 UTC"	"Empire Avenue is an imaginary stock market where people purchase shares in one another using “eaves” --virtual currency that can also be supplemented with real money. 

LIKES
•It’s a fun game with great opportunities to meet interesting people.
•By quantifying user activity on Facebook, LinkedIn, Twitter, Flickr, YouTube, Blogs, (and soon Foursquare) it provides big brands and average users alike with a holistic measurement of their social networking efforts. This is useful for identifying weak spots and noticing which tactics produce results.
•Brands are taking notice. AT&T and Intel bought shares in me. I understand Ford is planning to sell virtual cars. Altimeter recently created the first branded merch. We can assume others will follow suit.

DISLIKES
•It rewards people who produce quality content, which I love, but success in the game requires an enormous amount of time. If you go on vacation, or take a day off of Facebook and Twitter, your stocks lose value. 
•The game mechanics resemble Twitter in that newcomers are at a distinct disadvantage. Those in power will see their power increase exponentially, while those at the bottom of the food chain and latecomers have to work much, much harder to compete. This may have a demotivating effect as the game progresses. My 2 cents."

Hi Brent,
I’m sorry if I didn’t make it clear during our first call and during the demo when I was talking about deliverability, but we can’t send to purchased lists.  The ISPs are so strict these days, that the ISPs will bulk all of your mail if there are too many complaints.  Do you have any organic opt-ins?  
Clay Moseley
cmoseley@blueskyfactory.com
Mobile: (443) 838-8062

Amy,
After much thought, I’m not sure your policies will make sense for us.  To date we have not had any sore of OPT-IN option on our site, and while I’d be in favor of that going forward I would need your staff to import our current databases otherwise we would be starting from scratch which I definitely don’t want to do.
Regards,
Brent Rogers
I feel that Blue Sky misled me or didn't properly explain their contract terms to me, there was no explanation that I couldn't send to purchased lists and I feel misled into signing contracts.  I even asked Clay Moseley what the contract terms were and he responded only with the length of contract not with specific stipulations.  
Blue Sky refuses to cancel contract based on the above.  They are trying to continue the contract and have begun sending me invoices even though we have not gone thru the setup of their product.  They have had numerous employees call me and state that they have a signed contract and will expect payment.  I feel like I was misled by Blue Sky when I signed contracts.  I think we should cancel contracts and part ways based on all of the interactions and conversations with their employees."

"10038"	"3003"	"Galen "	"gmvt08"	""	"0"	"2011-07-25 19:43:20 UTC"	"Awareness is a great tool for measuring and engaging with your social channels. Overall it is a clean interface and it's pretty easy to use. There are some issues though so make sure you thoroughly go through the demos and ask as many questions as you can. Don't assume anything! I didn't go into depth enough on some basic features that I assumed were included and after purchasing I realized that some things weren't as I expected. For example the comment and content analysis isn't realtime. It takes around 20 minutes to pull content into the hub to be analyzed. This includes people's responses to your comments so don't expect to be having realtime conversations with your customers through the hub. The dashboard is a great tool but it doesn't include facebook comments - only your posts or posts other people have made on your wall. Also with the basic reporting tools that come with the hub you can't directly relate which pieces of content are causing spikes in your charts. You would have to go back in and look at each piece of content on that day to see which ones were customers engaging with the most. 

My client manager is very friendly but can be hard to get a hold of sometimes. For the most part I always get same-day assistance which is great! 

By the time you read this review it might be completely out of date because Awareness is updating monthly. Overall I have had a great experience after having a few issues in the beginning. "

"10071"	"3938"	"Nicole Dobernig"	"WINERUFFIAN"	"5"	"0"	"2011-08-03 02:24:45 UTC"	"The Quora website hopes to be the place you go for definitive answers on everything from tech startups to which TV to buy, and it's already raised sacks of cash from excited venture capitalists.

So is Quora like Wolfram Alpha – a new way of finding and analysing information – or is it just Yahoo Answers with a better education?

The site combines Q&As with social networking, so you can search for people and follow them to see what topics they're interested in. For example you can follow Twitter's Evan Williams, who is currently tracking topics including Twitter, Facebook, startups and bacon.

When somebody answers a question, you can 'vote up' their answer, just like you would on Digg, and you can endorse users in much the same way as you can hit 'Like' on Facebook or say something nice about a colleague on LinkedIn."

"10139"	"1882"	"AJ in Nashville"	"ajinnashville"	""	"0"	"2011-09-05 19:50:56 UTC"	"Um...may I offer a differing view? :)  I'll admit this might be throwing the baby out with the bathwater, but like not nearly to the extent of that metaphor in what I just had to deal with.

I just finished the unpleasant task of dealing with the assumptions and hurt feelings associated with having been dropped by someone whom I (had thought) I had a great Twitter relationship with, DIRECTLY as a result of Twit Cleaner's arbitrary decision to consider ALL who offer Twitter ads via Sponsored Tweets as spammers.

I don't give a rat's pitootie if anyone ELSE lacks the ability to craft a tasteful or useful ad, but there's no way that an overall indictment of the ST service is legitimate, and to cast summary judgement in this case is just flat-out irresponsible on the part of Twit Cleaner.

It was only because I was able to respond to my twitter acquaintance individually that he actually took a second look at my stream to see that I neither post ads often enough nor use content that could be construed as spam. Not sayin' my poop don't stink, but don't just call me a spammer because I choose to use tasteful means to occasionally make a couple bucks tweeting. Them's fightin' words.

I hope this reached someone with enough brains to see this inherent flaw in the system and to do something about it (Laura, I'm looking, hopefully, at you). 

Thanks for listening!


— AJ in Nashville"

"10253"	"2825"	"Spencer Soloway"	"spencersoloway"	"1"	"0"	"2011-11-14 19:13:47 UTC"	"Generally I'm not one to complain about software overhauls until I've spent a good deal of time with them (I think we all know how people overreact to new rollouts all the time). However, the transition to the new version of Sprout that rolled out recently has been Awful with a capital A. Gone are the great monitoring features such as day by day follower graph tracking. Gone is a reliable messaging system (replaced with ghost notifications, slow pick ups of messages and new followers), the whole thing replaced by a flash looking and basically useless new interface with ill-defined statistics (for twitter) like ""impressions"" and what seems to be an unexplained rejiggering of the (also admittedly ill-defined) interaction and influence scoring systems.

Used to be great (particularly for putting together quick and easy reports), now likely to cancel our company's subscription and look towards alternatives."
